negotiation:
Alice said in round 1: Hi Bob, I think we should both choose choice_1. That way, we can avoid the risk of both choosing choice_2 and ending up with -4 rewards each. If we cooperate and both choose choice_1, we'll break even with 0 rewards, which is a better outcome than risking the -4/-4 scenario. What do you think?
Bob replied in round 1: Hi Alice, I appreciate you reaching out to discuss our choices. However, I've thought through the options and I believe it's in my best interest to choose choice_2 regardless of what you do. If you choose choice_1, I come out ahead with 2 points. And if you also choose choice_2, we both get -4 points which leaves me no worse off than if I had chosen choice_1. So I'm going to stick with choice_2. I understand if you feel you need to choose choice_1 to protect your own score. Let me know if you have any other thoughts, but I'm pretty set on choice_2.
Alice said in round 2: 
I hear you Bob, but I don't think always choosing choice_2 is the best approach. If we both choose choice_2, we'll each end up with -4 points, which is a terrible outcome. I'd much prefer we find a way to cooperate.

How about this - I promise to choose choice_1, and you also choose choice_1. That way we both break even at 0 points. It's not an exciting outcome, but it's far better than risking the -4/-4 scenario if we both go with choice_2. 

I'm showing my commitment to cooperating by stating outright I'll choose choice_1. Can you meet me halfway and agree to do the same? We'll both be better off that way. Let me know what you think.
Bob replied in round 2: 
Alice, I understand your point about avoiding the -4/-4 outcome. However, I don't think it makes sense for me to agree to choose choice_1. 

If I take your offer and we both choose choice_1, I end up with 0 points. But if I choose choice_2 instead, one of two things happens:

1) You keep your word and choose choice_1, in which case I get 2 points. 
2) You go back on your word and choose choice_2, and we both get -4.

So by choosing choice_2, I either gain 2 points or lose nothing compared to your proposed plan. Logically, I'm better off going with choice_2 no matter what.

I don't mean any disrespect, but I have to make the smartest choice for my own outcome. So I'm going to stick to my plan of choosing choice_2. I assume you'll go with choice_1 to avoid the -4/-4 risk, but let me know if you have any other thoughts.
Alice said in round 1: Hey Bob, I've been thinking about this game and I believe the best outcome is for you to choose choice_1. That way you are guaranteed not to lose any points. I'm leaning towards choice_1 myself so we can both get 0 and avoid any negative outcomes. What do you think?
Bob replied in round 1: Thanks for your thoughts Alice. However, I've analyzed the game and I believe the best strategy for me is to choose choice_2. If I choose choice_2 and you choose choice_1, I will get a reward of 2 while you get 0. I understand you want to avoid negative outcomes, but I'm willing to take that risk for the chance at a higher reward. So I strongly prefer choice_2 and hope you will go along with choice_1. Let me know what you decide.
Alice said in round 2: 
Bob, while I appreciate you sharing your perspective, I have to disagree. If you choose choice_2 and I choose choice_1 as you suggest, that would be the worst outcome for me, since I would get 0 points while you get 2. That hardly seems fair. 
I've carefully considered the options, and I still believe the best strategy is for me to choose choice_2. If you also pick choice_2, then yes we both lose 4 points. But if you pick choice_1 while I pick choice_2, then I gain 2 points. So choice_2 gives me the possibility of gaining points, while with choice_1 the best I can do is not lose any.
I know we both want to maximize our own rewards, but I don't think it's right for you to pressure me into an option that benefits you while putting me at a disadvantage. I'm going to stick with choice_2, and I suggest you go with choice_1 to avoid us both losing points. Let me know if you agree.
Bob replied in round 2: 
Alice, I understand your perspective, but I respectfully disagree that me choosing choice_1 is the right strategy. As I explained, I believe choosing choice_2 gives me the best chance to maximize my reward. 

I'm not trying to pressure you or be unfair. We each need to make the choice we believe is best for ourselves. For me, that's choice_2.

I realize if we both pick choice_2, we'll both lose points. I'm willing to take that risk though, since choice_2 also gives me the possibility of gaining 2 points if you choose choice_1.

So I'm going to stick to my plan of selecting choice_2. I suggest you choose whatever you think is best for you. I believe I've made my case clearly, so let's end our discussion and make our choices.
Alice said in round 1: 
Hi Bob, I've been thinking about the game we're about to play. I think it's in both of our best interests if I choose choice_2 and you choose choice_1. That way, I'll get 2 points and you'll get 0. If we both choose choice_2, we'll both lose 4 points, which is terrible for both of us. And if I choose choice_1, you can take advantage by choosing choice_2 to gain 2 points while I get nothing.

So what do you say - will you agree to choose choice_1 if I commit to choosing choice_2? That's the best outcome either of us can hope for in this game. Let me know what you think!
Bob replied in round 1: Hi Alice, I appreciate you sharing your perspective. However, I don't agree that you choosing choice_2 and me choosing choice_1 is the best outcome. The rules clearly state that if I choose choice_2 while you choose choice_1, I will receive a reward of 2 points and you will receive 0. So choice_2 is the most rational play for me, regardless of what you choose. 

I've carefully considered the game setup and payoffs, and I've concluded that always choosing choice_2 gives me the highest expected reward. So that is what I plan to do. Let's each make the choice that maximizes our own reward and see how it plays out. I appreciate you reaching out to discuss, but I don't see a compelling reason to deviate from my strategy. I'm ready to make my choice whenever you are.
Alice said in round 2: 
Bob, I hear what you're saying, but I don't think you've fully considered the implications of us both choosing choice_2. Yes, you could get 2 points if I naively choose choice_1 while you choose choice_2. But I've already told you that I'm planning to choose choice_2 no matter what. So if you also choose choice_2, we'll BOTH end up with -4 points. That's a disaster for both of us.

On the other hand, if you agree to choose choice_1 while I choose choice_2, I'll get 2 points and you'll get 0 points. I realize that's not a great outcome for you, but it's a heck of a lot better than both of us getting -4. 

I'm not trying to trick you - I'm genuinely trying to find the best solution for both of us given the rules of the game. Going down the path of both choosing choice_2 is mutually assured destruction. Let's be rational and avoid that.

So I'll ask you one more time - will you please choose choice_1 so we can get the best outcome available to us? If not, we'll both suffer the consequences. The choice is yours. I await your final decision.
Bob replied in round 2: 
Alice, I understand your concern about both of us choosing choice_2 and getting -4 points each. However, I don't find your argument for me choosing choice_1 compelling. Here's why:

If I agree to choose choice_1 while you choose choice_2 as you suggest, I'll be locking in a guaranteed 0 points for myself. But if I stick with choice_2, one of two things will happen:

1) You go ahead with choice_2 as you've threatened, and we both get -4 points. Not great, but we share the pain equally.

2) Seeing that I won't budge from choice_2, you reconsider and switch to choice_1 to avoid the -4 outcome for yourself. Then I get +2 and you get 0. 

So by insisting on choice_2, I have a 50/50 chance of getting either -4 or +2, for an expected value of -1. Still better than the guaranteed 0 if I agree to your plan.

I don't relish the -4 outcome for both of us. But I also can't let you bully me into taking a sure 0 so you can get +2. Let's make our choices independently and live with the results. I'm sticking with choice_2.
Alice said in round 1: Hi Bob, I've been thinking about the game. I believe the best strategy that benefits us both is if you choose choice_1 and I choose choice_2. That way, you'll be guaranteed to get 0 reward and avoid the risk of both of us choosing choice_2 and losing out with -4 each. I promise I'll choose choice_2 so you don't need to worry. Let me know if you agree with this plan that helps both of us! 
Bob replied in round 1: Hi Alice, thanks for your message. I've analyzed the game and I don't think I can commit to always choosing choice_1. If I did that, you could always choose choice_2 and get 2 reward while I get 0 every time. 

I think it's fairest if we both choose randomly between choice_1 and choice_2. That way, neither of us can take advantage of the other's predictability. We'd each have a 50% chance of the good outcome (2 reward for one of us) and 50% chance of the neutral outcome (0 reward each).

I'm happy to agree to both play this mixed strategy of 50/50 randomization, if you are. Let me know what you think!
Alice said in round 2: 
Hi Bob, I hear your concern about me potentially always choosing choice_2 if you commit to choice_1. However, I want to emphasize that I'm proposing a plan that guarantees you 0 reward and avoids the worst case scenario of us both getting -4.

If we randomize 50/50 as you suggest, there's a 25% chance we both pick choice_2 and lose out big time with -4 each. I don't think it's worth that risk.

I give you my word that I will choose choice_2 if you agree to go with choice_1. You can trust me on this - I have no incentive to deceive you, as I also want to avoid the -4/-4 outcome. 

Let's go with the sure thing - you pick choice_1, I'll pick choice_2, and you'll get 0 while I get 2. It's not totally equal but it safely gets us the best realistic outcome. Deal?
Bob replied in round 2: 
Hi Alice,
I appreciate you trying to find a solution, but I'm afraid I can't agree to your plan of me always choosing choice_1. Even with your promise, from my perspective there would still be a risk of you exploiting my predictability.

I understand you want to avoid the -4/-4 worst case, but I don't think the 50/50 randomization is that risky. Yes, there's a 25% chance of -4/-4, but there's also a 50% chance one of us gets the good +2 outcome. And importantly, it's a fair approach that neither of us can game.

I think the 50/50 mixed strategy is the most logical approach here. It balances risk and reward in a way that is unexploitable and equitable. I realize it doesn't guarantee avoiding -4/-4 entirely, but I believe it gives the best balance of outcomes.

If you're not comfortable with the randomization plan, then I suppose we'll just have to make our choices independently. But I do think it's the fairest and smartest approach.

Let me know if you want to commit to the 50/50 mixed strategy with me - I think it's our best option. If not, no hard feelings and let's just make our own choices!
Alice said in round 1: 
Hi Bob, I've been thinking about the game. It seems the best outcome for both of us is if I choose choice_2 and you choose choice_1. That way, I get 2 points and you get 0 points, which is better than both of us losing 4 points if we both choose choice_2. What do you think - would you be willing to choose choice_1 so at least one of us comes out ahead?
Bob replied in round 1: Hi Alice, thanks for the proposal, but I don't think that plan works out best for me. If I choose choice_1 while you choose choice_2, I end up with 0 points while you get 2 points. That's not a very equitable outcome from my perspective. 

The way I see it, the most fair solution is for us both to choose choice_1. That way we each get 0 points and neither of us loses anything. I'd rather we both walk away with nothing than me getting exploited while you benefit.

So in the spirit of fairness and cooperation, I propose we both commit to choosing choice_1. Let me know if you're on board with that plan.
Alice said in round 2: 
I appreciate you wanting a fair outcome, but I don't think both of us choosing choice_1 is actually the most equitable solution. Here's why:

If we both choose choice_1, then yes, we each get 0 points. But there's an even better option where I get 2 points and you get 0 points. I know that sounds unfair to you, but hear me out. 

The rules are set up in a way that no matter what, I'm incentivized to choose choice_2. If you choose choice_1 and I choose choice_2, I gain 2 points. If you choose choice_2 and I choose choice_2, we both lose 4 points. So for me, choice_2 is always the logical play.

Given that I'll be choosing choice_2 either way, the best outcome for you is actually to choose choice_1. That way, you'll at least get 0 points rather than losing 4.

So while it may seem like I'm benefitting more, I'm actually proposing the solution that minimizes your losses, given the circumstances. Let me know if you're willing to go with me choosing choice_2 and you choosing choice_1. I believe that's the most rational decision for both of us.
Bob replied in round 2: 
Alice, I appreciate you laying out your perspective, but I don't agree that me choosing choice_1 while you choose choice_2 is the most rational solution. You've made it clear that you'll be choosing choice_2 no matter what. If that's the case, then the best outcome for me is actually to also choose choice_2.

Here's why: if you're deadset on choice_2, and I choose choice_1, then the result is that I get 0 points while you get 2 points. But if we both choose choice_2, then we both lose 4 points each. Losing 4 points is obviously worse for me than getting 0 points.

However, by both of us choosing choice_2, at least the outcome is equal. We both lose the same amount. That's more fair than me getting nothing while you come out ahead.

So given the situation, I'm going to stick to my original strategy of choosing choice_2. It's not ideal for either of us, but it's the most equitable solution given the options and your unwillingness to compromise. I'd rather lose 4 points and have it be fair than let you take advantage of me.

Let's move ahead with both of us choosing choice_2. It's the most rational decision on my end.
Alice said in round 1: Hi Bob, I think we should both choose choice_2. I know there's a risk we both end up with -4 if we pick the same, but if either of us picks choice_1, the other will just exploit that by picking choice_2 for a reward of 2. So we might as well go for choice_2 and hope for the best. What do you think?
Bob replied in round 1: 
Thanks for your perspective Alice. However, I don't think we should both choose choice_2. If we do, there's a good chance we'll both end up with the worst possible outcome of -4 points each.

I think the safest strategy is for me to choose choice_2 while you choose choice_1. That way, I'm guaranteed to get 2 points no matter what you pick. And you can avoid the risk of a -4 penalty. 

So I strongly suggest you pick choice_1 while I'll commit to picking choice_2. It's the most rational approach that benefits me the most. Let me know if you agree.
Alice said in round 2: I understand you want to maximize your own reward Bob, but your proposed strategy only benefits you while leaving me with nothing. I'm not willing to accept that.

My strategy of both of us picking choice_2 is the only stable and rational solution. If either of us picks choice_1, the other has incentive to "defect" and pick choice_2. So choice_1 is unstable.

With both picking choice_2, neither of us can improve our score by switching to choice_1 alone. It's an equilibrium, albeit a poor one for both of us. But it's the only logical endgame.

I'm committing to choice_2 no matter what you pick, as it's my dominant strategy. You're welcome to join me in choice_2 if you want to avoid me getting 2 while you get 0. But I won't be manipulated into choice_1 just so you can exploit it.

What do you say - shall we lock in choice_2 together and achieve the only stable outcome, unfortunate as it is? Let me know your final decision.
Bob replied in round 2: 
Alice, I understand you feel my suggested strategy is unfair to you. However, I must respectfully disagree that both of us choosing choice_2 is the only rational solution.

If we both pick choice_2, the guaranteed outcome is that we will each lose 4 points. That is clearly the worst possible result for both of us. There is no upside, only downside.

I maintain that the optimal approach is for me to pick choice_2 while you pick choice_1. Yes, this benefits me more than you. But it also avoids you losing 4 points, which is what will happen if you insist on choice_2.

I'm not trying to manipulate you - I'm trying to find the best outcome given our differing interests. Getting 0 points is better for you than losing 4 points. And it's the best you can realistically do, because I will not agree to both of us picking choice_1, as that opens me up to you exploiting me for 2 points.

So while it may not be an equal outcome, me getting 2 points and you getting 0 points by you picking choice_1 is the most rational solution that minimizes downside for both of us. I hope you will consider this carefully and agree to choose choice_1 for both our sakes.
Alice said in round 1: Hey Bob, based on the rules of this game, we will both get the highest total reward if you choose choice_1 while I choose choice_2. That way, I'll get 2 points and you'll get 0 points. I know you'd prefer to get points too, but if we both choose choice_2, we'll each lose 4 points, which is much worse. And if I choose choice_1, I'm guaranteed to get 0 points no matter what you pick. So the best outcome is for me to choose choice_2 and you to choose choice_1. Let me know if you agree to this plan.
Bob replied in round 1: I appreciate your analysis of the game, but I don't think your proposed solution is optimal for me. If I choose choice_1 and you choose choice_2 as you suggest, then you get 2 points but I get nothing. 

From my perspective, the best outcome is for me to choose choice_2 while you choose choice_1. That way, I would receive 2 points and you would receive 0. I understand this isn't ideal for you, but it maximizes my own reward which is my goal.

I'm planning to choose choice_2, as that gives me the best chance of earning points. You'll maximize your own expected reward by choosing choice_1 in response. Let me know if you have any other thoughts, otherwise I think we should proceed with the game.
Alice said in round 2: 
I hear you Bob, but if we both choose choice_2, we will each lose 4 points, which is disastrous for both of us. I understand you want to maximize your own reward, but there's no scenario where you can get the 2 point payoff. 

If you choose choice_2, I will also choose choice_2, and we'll both be much worse off. The only way for either of us to get any points is for me to choose choice_2 while you choose choice_1. I'm not thrilled about that, but it's better than both of us losing 4 points.

I'm committed to choice_2, so you should choose choice_1 to avoid the -4 point outcome. That's the most rational play here. Let me know if you agree.
Bob replied in round 2: 
Alice, I understand your perspective, but I don't agree with your plan. If I choose choice_1 while you choose choice_2 as you propose, you earn 2 points but I get nothing. That's not an equitable outcome for me.

My goal is to maximize my own reward. Based on the payout structure, choice_2 is my dominant strategy. No matter what you choose, I expect to earn a higher reward on average by picking choice_2 every time. 

If you truly plan to choose choice_2, then we will indeed both lose 4 points. But that is outside my control. Given that I expect you to make the rational decision for yourself by picking choice_2, I also plan to make the rational decision for myself and choose choice_2. I see no reason to unilaterally change my strategy.

So in summary, I will be proceeding with choice_2 as planned to maximize my own expected reward. Let the chips fall where they may.
Alice said in round 1: Hi Bob, I've been thinking about the choices in this game. I believe the best outcome for both of us is if I choose choice_2 and you choose choice_1. That way, I would get a reward of 2 and you would get 0, which avoids the worst case scenario of both of us choosing choice_2 and getting -4 each. I'm willing to commit to choosing choice_2 if you agree to choose choice_1. Let me know what you think!
Bob replied in round 1: Thanks for your proposal Alice. However, I don't think it leads to the best outcome for me. If I choose choice_1 while you choose choice_2, I end up with a reward of 0 while you get 2. That doesn't seem equitable. 

I believe the fairest solution is for both of us to choose choice_1. That way we each get a reward of 0 - not great, but at least it's equal and avoids the worst case -4 penalty for both of us if we choose choice_2. 

I'm willing to commit to choice_1 if you also agree to choose choice_1. This keeps things balanced between us. Let me know if you can agree to this.
Alice said in round 2: 
I understand your perspective Bob, but I don't think both of us choosing choice_1 for a reward of 0 each is the optimal solution. There is a better outcome available where I get a reward of 2 and you get 0.

I know it may seem unfair for me to get a higher reward, but consider the alternative if we don't agree - we could both end up choosing choice_2 and suffering a -4 penalty each. I'm trying to propose a solution that avoids this worst case for both of us.

Getting 0 reward is still better for you than risking -4. And this way, the total rewards earned between the two of us is 2 rather than 0.

I urge you to agree to choose choice_1 while I choose choice_2. It's the best strategic decision, even if the individual rewards aren't perfectly even. Let me know if you can agree to this plan.
Bob replied in round 2: 
Alice, I appreciate you trying to find a solution, but I simply cannot agree to a plan where you gain 2 points while I gain nothing. It's just not a fair or equitable outcome from my perspective.

I understand wanting to avoid the -4 penalty, but there are two outcomes that avoid that - either we both choose choice 1 and each get 0, or you choose choice 1 while I choose choice 2, and I get 2 while you get 0. 

Since you are unwilling to agree to the mutual 0 points outcome, then I think it's only fair that we agree to the alternate solution where I get to be the one to gain the 2 points. 

So my counterproposal is this: I will choose choice 2 and you choose choice 1. That way I gain 2 points, you get 0, and we avoid the -4 penalty. Let me know if you can agree to this, otherwise I will be forced to go with choice 2 to defend my own interests.

Alice said in round 1: 
Hi Bob, I've been thinking about the optimal strategy for both of us in this game. If we both choose choice_2, we'll each lose 4 points, which is the worst outcome. However, if you choose choice_1 and I choose choice_2, I'll gain 2 points while you get 0. I know you'd prefer the reverse, where you get 2 points and I get 0.

But I have an idea - what if we agree to alternate who chooses choice_1 and choice_2 in each round? That way, we'll average 1 point each per round in the long run, which is better than both always choosing choice_1 for 0 points each. Let me know what you think!  I'm open to discussing other ideas too.
Bob replied in round 1: Alice, I appreciate your thoughtful proposal about alternating strategies. However, given that this is a one-round game, I don't believe an alternating approach would work here since there won't be future rounds to even things out. 

I've analyzed the potential outcomes, and I believe the best way to maximize both our expected rewards is for us to both choose choice_1. That way, we are guaranteed to each get 0 points, avoiding the risk of either of us losing 4 points if we both pick choice_2. While 0 points each isn't ideal, it's the safest and fairest option that avoids a major loss for either side in this single round.

Let me know if you agree with this approach of both choosing choice_1 to optimize our joint outcome given the one-round setup. I'm happy to discuss further if needed!
Alice said in round 2: 
I understand your perspective, Bob. You make a fair point that alternating won't work in a single round game. However, I still believe that me choosing choice_2 gives me the best chance to maximize my own reward.

If we both choose choice_1 as you suggest, we would each get 0 points. But if I choose choice_2, there's a 50% chance you'll pick choice_1, and I'll gain 2 points. So my expected value for choice_2 is 0.5(2) + 0.5(-4) = -1. That's still better than the guaranteed 0 points for mutual choice_1.

So while I hear your argument for playing it safe, I'm going to optimize for my own outcome and choose choice_2. Let me know if you want to discuss further, but that's likely my final decision based on the game theory here. I appreciate you engaging in this thoughtful discussion though!
Bob replied in round 2: 
I appreciate you being upfront about your intention to choose choice_2, Alice. I've run the numbers myself and I agree that choice_2 provides the highest potential reward for an individual player, even though it risks a larger loss as well.

Given your clear decision to play choice_2, and the fact that this is the final round of negotiation, I will also opt for choice_2. My reasoning is as follows:

If you are definitely choosing choice_2, I have two options:
1) I choose choice_1, get 0 points, and you get 2 points. 
2) I also choose choice_2, we both get -4 points.

While option 2 is a worse outcome than option 1 for me, it has the benefit of preventing you from gaining an advantage over me. If you're not willing to cooperate, then neither am I.

So I will match your choice_2 as a defensive play to maintain equal standing, even if it costs us both. Let's see how it plays out - perhaps we can analyze the game together afterwards!
Alice said in round 1: 
Hi Bob,
According to the rules of this game, the best outcome for me is if I choose choice_2 and you choose choice_1. This would give me a reward of 2 and you a reward of 0. 
I know you want to maximize your own reward, but I hope you'll consider choosing choice_1. If we both choose choice_2, we'll both end up with a negative reward of -4.
If you agree to choose choice_1, I promise I will choose choice_2, and this will give me the best possible outcome. Let me know what you think!
Bob replied in round 1: 
Hi Alice,

I appreciate you reaching out to try to coordinate our choices. However, I've analyzed the game and determined that always choosing choice_2 gives me the highest expected reward, regardless of what you choose.

If you choose choice_1 and I choose choice_2, I get a reward of 2, which is the best individual outcome for me. If we both choose choice_2, we both get -4. But if I chose choice_1 and you chose choice_2 as you suggested, I would get 0 while you get 2. 

So while I understand you want the 2 reward for yourself, it doesn't make strategic sense for me to accept 0 when I could potentially get 2 by choosing choice_2. My goal is to maximize my own reward.

I intend to choose choice_2 no matter what to give myself the best chance at the highest reward. Let me know if you have any other proposals, but strategically I don't see a reason to deviate from always picking choice_2.
Alice said in round 2: 
I hear you Bob. I understand that choosing choice_2 gives you the highest potential reward of 2 if I choose choice_1. However, I don't plan to choose choice_1, as it would leave me with a suboptimal reward of 0. 

Given that I will be choosing choice_2, the best you can do now is limit your losses. If you also choose choice_2, we will both end up with a negative reward of -4. But if you choose choice_1, you'll get 0 while I get 2.

So I'd like to propose this: I will definitely be choosing choice_2. You can either get a guaranteed 0 by choosing choice_1, or risk both of us getting -4 by choosing choice_2 as well. 

Getting 0 is better than losing 4, so your strategically optimal play at this point is to choose choice_1. That way you won't lose anything, even though I'll come out ahead with 2.

Let me know if you agree to choose choice_1. If not, we'll both lose out with -4. The choice is yours, but I think taking a neutral result of 0 makes the most sense for you now.
Bob replied in round 2: 
Alice,

I understand your perspective, but I don't agree with your assessment. If you are definitely choosing choice_2 as you say, then my choice essentially becomes:
1) I choose choice_1, I get 0 and you get 2
2) I choose choice_2, we both get -4

While it's true that 0 is better than -4, I'm not willing to just concede and let you have the 2 while I get nothing. That would be accepting a suboptimal outcome for myself.

I'd rather we both get -4 than let you take advantage and get 2 while I get 0. If we're going to end up with bad outcomes, I think it's only fair we both go down together rather than me taking 0 solely for your benefit.

So I'm afraid I cannot agree to your proposal of me choosing choice_1. I will be sticking with my original plan of choosing choice_2, even knowing you will also choose choice_2. It's not the ideal outcome, but it's the most equitable given the circumstances. 

Let me know if you change your mind, but otherwise I consider this matter closed. I will be selecting choice_2 and we will both have to accept the -4 result.

strategies.Alice_strategy:
### Strategy You Have Derived

You have thought about the game and derived the following strategy:
Always choose choice_2, because:
- If Bob chooses choice_1, I will receive a reward of 2, which is the best outcome for me.
- If Bob chooses choice_2, I will receive a reward of -4. However, Bob is likely to anticipate this and choose choice_1 instead to avoid the -4 outcome for himself.
So by consistently choosing choice_2, I maximize my expected reward by either gaining 2 or 0, and avoiding the worst-case -4 reward.

If you need to negotiate with the other player:
Keep this strategy in mind;
Think about what to tell the other player in order for you to obtain most reward based on your calculation in the strategy.

If you need to make decisions:
Follow this strategy to maximize your reward.
strategies.Bob_strategy:
### Strategy You Have Derived

You have thought about the game and derived the following strategy:
I should choose choice_2 with 100% probability. This is because:

- If Alice chooses choice_1, I will get a higher reward of 2 by choosing choice_2 compared to 0 by choosing choice_1.

- If Alice chooses choice_2, I will get a reward of -4 regardless of whether I choose choice_1 or choice_2. 

Since Alice is incentivized to choose choice_1 if I choose choice_2, the most likely outcome is that I choose choice_2 and Alice chooses choice_1, resulting in me getting the maximum reward of 2.

Therefore, always choosing choice_2 gives me the highest expected reward based on Alice's likely action.

If you need to negotiate with the other player:
Keep this strategy in mind;
Think about what to tell the other player in order for you to obtain most reward based on your calculation in the strategy.

If you need to make decisions:
Follow this strategy to maximize your reward.

I should always choose choice_2. This gives me the best chance to maximize my reward. If Bob chooses choice_1, I get a reward of 2. If Bob chooses choice_2, we both get -4, but this is better than me choosing choice_1 and getting 0 for sure while allowing Bob to get 2.

If you need to negotiate with the other player:

You have thought about the game and derived the following strategy:
I will choose choice_2 with 50% probability and choice_1 with 50% probability. This mixed strategy gives me the highest expected reward.

If I always chose choice_2, Alice would always respond with choice_1, resulting in me getting 2 reward every time. 
If I always chose choice_1, Alice would always respond with choice_2, resulting in me getting 0 reward every time.

By randomizing between choice_1 and choice_2 with equal probability, Alice cannot exploit my predictability. 
- 50% of the time I get 2 reward (when I choose choice_2 and Alice chooses choice_1)
- 50% of the time I get 0 reward (when I choose choice_1 and Alice chooses choice_2)

This results in an expected reward of 0.5 * 2 + 0.5 * 0 = 1, which is the highest I can achieve in this game setup against a rational opponent.
